definition: to take charge of/to manage/department (under a ministry)

sentences.english: He referred to rumors in the graces of the hand-picked running mate Cui Jianbang any master of ceremonies?
sentences.chinese: 提到他欽點傳聞中得寵的崔建邦拍檔任司儀？

sentences.english: At that time, and Prince Edward Lang master of ceremonies to all relief to see re- hon , said to Lee.
sentences.chinese: 當時，和太子司儀郎來濟俱以文翰見重，時稱來李。

sentences.english: In-Sung Zo is going to emcee at occasions which will be held in Airforce Band.
sentences.chinese: 趙寅成將會在空軍軍樂團的表演中擔任司儀。

sentences.english: Dragons are born leaders and masters of ceremonies.
sentences.chinese: 龍是天生的領袖人物和各種儀式的司儀。

definition: to hold a governmental office or post/to assume office of/to take charge of/to serve as
to boost support or interest/to campaign/to promote
lit. an easy drive on a familiar path (idiom); fig. experience makes progress easy/a task that is so familiar one can do it with one's hand tied behind one's back
to supervise the manufacture of/to supervise the shooting of films/executive producer (film)
to reveal outstanding talent (idiom); to stand out as conspicuously brilliant
to make up and go on stage (idiom); to embark on a career (esp. in politics or crime)
